div.p: THE MALADY AND REMEDY OF VEXATIONS AND VNIVST ARRESTS AND ACTIONS.
HVMBLY PRESENTED TO THE GRAVE consideration and iust determination of the High Court of Parliament, as matters of speciall concernment to all the Commons of England.
LONDON, Printed September 24. 1646.

div.head: THE MALADY AND REMEDY OF VEXATIONS AND VNIVST Arrests and Actions.
div.p: IT hath been observed, and by wofull experience found • rue, that the Innovati • n and alteration of any fundamentall point of the Common Law, hath proved dangerous and destructive, to the peoples liberties; therefore it hath been the wisdome and care of our Grandees and wise Senators in former ages to provide for, and looke unto in the first place, to have the Ancient Laws and their Liberties confirmed, which neither by intreaty nor force of Armes (though often • ssayed and attempted) the Commons of this Kingdome could ever be drawne or forced to fo • go or desert, but have against all opposition, overcomming all d • fficulties c • nstantly persevered in maintaining their Lawes, and vindicating their Liberties.

Duke William of Normandy after he had brought England under his obedience, attempted, and would h • ve ruled by his owne Law, and began to Governe a • l after the Customes of Normandy, whereat the N • bility being much grieved, and the people therewith much sadd • d, and new troubles being ready to break forth: He upon the C • mmons requ • st▪ and for quieting of the People by his Charter Confirmed, which he twice before h • d by oath promised, and gave commandement to his Justiciars to see those Lawes of King Edward, called the Conf • ssor, to be inviolably observed, the great Charter of Libert • es maintained throughout the whol • Kingd • me; being to the same eff ct, confirmed after by King Henry the first, who not only pleas • d his subj • ct • in their Relievements, but likewis • in their suffering • , by • un • shing the chiefe ministers of their exactions; and the same was afterward ratified and m • de good by King John and Henry the third, and by many Parliaments since, by this present Parliament, and by the Petition o • Right.

Now there is not any thing which more nearely concerneth, and which the Law more favou • eth and regardeth, then the liberty and freedom of a mans person: And not without great reason, seeing a mans liberty is so pretious and of that E • timation, that the same not undeservedly is valued above al other worldly and Externall Blessings, and without which man can take little delight in what
else he enjoyeth; for Imprisonment of all other afflictions is one of the heaviest oftentimes worse then death, for thereby a man is kept in a lingring death, and is continually dying, so tender a care and due regard and provision therefore hath the Law ever had for the preservation of the peoples liberties, and freeing mens persons from Vexations of unjust Actions, that by the Constitutions and Fundamentall Lawes of this Kingdome no men were s • bject to Imprisonment for debt, or other personall actions which were not criminall and capitall, but only their goods were lyable to be charged, yea, not their lands, but in some speciall cases.

Yet since by some late Statutes, made upon faire and specious pretences for the Imprisoning mens bodies for debt, the liberty of the people hath been much encroached upon, and many thousands thereby made wretched and miserable, yea, and have starved in Prison. It is not to be told what devises and fained Actions and causelesse and unjust Arrests, through the cunning dealing and crafty devises of Atturneys and Sollicitors are since daily framed and executed▪ to the grievous vexation and oppression of the people, whereby able and well minded men by such causelesse Arrests and groundlesse actions are utterly undone, especially Merchants and Trades-men, who by such unjust attempts and wicked practises a • e causelesly cast into prison, and so deprived of their liberty, spoiled of their Trade, and have lost their Credit, whereby many of them are quite ruined and undone, being made a prey to Bayliffes and Sergeants, the catterpillers of the Common-wealth and enslaved to the willes and lusts of hard hearted Gaolors, when often the Actions be either meerely of Malice▪ or for Vexation devised, or the debt but triviall and inconsiderable, if any at all:

Yet so high and for so great summes be the same Actions as the parties imprisoned cannot, (though men of considerable estates) procure baile for answering such Actions, and so most injuriously still detained in prison, till either by death they bee acqu • tted, or otherwise being deprived of all other meanes and hopes, constrained to submit and enslave themselves to the lusts and mercilesse cruelty of their adversaries: Now are not these doings, these practises, these kind of men more dangerous, more destructive to the welfare and liberty of the people then open robberies, high way theeves, or Bulglaries?

For hee that robs or steales from a man, can take no more then what he finds in his present possession, or that he is able to carry away; whereas the other by such Arrests, and malicious (yea, for the most part groundlesse and causelesse) actions seases on a mans person, robs him of his liberty, spoiles him of his trade, his credit, and all his meanes of subsistence and livelihood at once, his wife and children left desolate and forsaken, an oppression the more grievous and intollerable, the same being done by colour of Law and countenance of Authority, which ought to be the refuge and sanctuary of the innocent and oppressed.

And while the pa • ty thus grieved and imprisoned, strives to recover what hee had so lost by such illegall oppressions, his misery is increased, the cure more dangerous then the disease, and by seeking to avoyd one inconvenience, is hurried into a greater mischiefe, being driven to consume the remainder of his estate, if any be left him, by an endlesse and fruitlesse suite to the enriching of Atturneyes and Sollicitours, whose greatnesse and wealth rises from the ruines and spoyling of the people: For these men of Law and their Confederates, as Under-Sheriffes, Bayliffes, Gaolours, and their Subordinate Officers, the Catterpillers of this Kingdome, who with their uncontrolled exactions and extortions, eat up the Free-borne people of this Nation, as if it were an act as lawfull and necessary as to eat bread.

And as there is a neare relation; and correspondencie betweene the Druggest and Apothecary, the Clothier and the Wollen-Draper, the Brasier and the Tinker, so there is no lesse correspondencie betweene these Petti-foggers and Officers of Prisons, by which they abuse and inthrall the Free-borne people: By all which it is apparent, notwithstanding the many and often confirmed Lawes for the preservation of the peoples just Liberties, wee onely have the dead letter, shew and shaddow of the Continuation thereof, being in truth utterly deprived of all benefit thereby, while wee are thus subject to these kindes of Arrests and Imprisonments, from which no man can say, hee is free, save a few priviledged persons; whose posterity and children are still under, and left unto the same vassallage and bondage.

Thus by these Injurious u • ju • t and fained Actions and Arrests, we that were and ever have been so accompted the most Free people, are become the most enslaved people, yea, a Kingdome of slaves, whereof we have been for a long time regardlesse, till the same have insensibly overtaken us, and if the same be not spe • d • ly provided for and remedied, wee shall never be able to recover and prevent this oppression and calamity, which I conceive the more to be minded, the same being so weighty a businesse, as nothing is of a more higher concernment, in regard we have no fitting provision for the prevention of this mischiefe and malady, till when and while the Free-borne people are subjected, and left open to such causelesse and contentious actions and arrests; all your other Lawes that are or shall be made, though never so faire, specious, or promising, are vaine and fruitlesse, seeing they no wayes secure mens persons, nor provide for their Libertys.

So as though a man owe not any thing, but have sufficiency for the discharge of his just debts and credits with an overplus for the comfortable subsistence of himself, his wife and family, and whereby hee may the better put himselfe forth for the preferment and advancement of his children; yet notwithstanding all this, he is subject, and both daily and hourely in danger to be robbed and spoiled of all he hath, not by high-way-men and theeves, for these may bee avoyded or secured, if discovered aforehand, either by turning out of the way, or Valour, or helpe of friends, neighbours and countrey be rescued, not by Pirats and Sea-Rovers, from these a man may by flight or fighting escape and gaine a safe harbour: But by such as be the abjects of men, such as Job tells us, He disdained to set with dogges of his flockes, by a company of Atturneyes, Solicitours, Sergeants and Promoters, nay; by any one of these Catterpillers, and Earth wormes, who being set on mischiefe, or other displeasure causelessely conceived, or often-times wickedly hired thereunto, upon a pretended, fained, or forged Action of an hundred pounds, a thousand pounds, or ten thousand pounds by addition or increase of a cypher; (though a man be not in the least liable to any such action) can take and seaze upon his person, of what degree soever he be, (except a few priviledged persons) and cast him into prison to his utter overthrow, and the destruction of his wife and children, no avoydance, no place nor sanctuary there is against these kind of men, Whosoever comes under their power, is in the way of destruction.

Wherefore, to free the Kingdome of this lamentable Vassallage and bondage, and more easily to breake this iron yoke of oppression, under which the whole hand groneth and waiteth with a longing expectation of deliverance, if the High Judicature and Court of Parliament, doe really intend and desire, as in all their Protestations, Declarations, and Remonstrances they have professed and held forth to the world, to restore us to our native and pristine liberties: It much behoveth them to improve their interests, and by their wisdomes and power, for the freeing this people from this thraldome and oppression speedily to provide some good and wholesome Lawes for the prevention and utter abolishing of all Vexations and unjust Actions and Arrests for pretended debts, by which many thousand Families are undone, and many able and well minded men at this day, are east and lye in the devouring prisons under a miserable servitude and oppression, which by the frequentnesse and daily practice is common, and so insupportable, that the same is become one of the great burthens
and grievances of the Kingdome, which is the rather to be minded by the Parliament for that this injustice and injurious dealing towards the people, is done and countenanced by and under the name and title of magisteriall Authority, as a colourable pretext to those their unjust proceedings.

Therefore to neglect such an opportunity as this, which is now put into your hands (noble Senators and grave Consins) to doe good for the people for whom you are intrusted, were utterly a fault, and to passe by this mischiefe, in leaving us without hope, without comfort, prostitute to so great a destruction, wou • d bee no small blot and blemish to the proceedings of this Honourable Senate, for to private men it is sufficient and commendable to abstaine from wrong: But for you that be the Supreme Magistracy and Rulers of the people, to see and provide that none under you doe wrong, for conniving at, or abetting the faults and miscarriages of their subordinate Officers, Superiours make them seeme, and may truly be said to be their owne.

Now for Redresse wherof, I as a free commoner of England, am bold to apply my selfe, and make my humble addresse unto you in the • ame and behalfe of my selfe and many thousands free borne of this Nation, spoiled of their birth-right and liberty, now languishing in prisons by these kind of Arrests and groundlesse vexatious Actions, which our suttle and malicius adversaries, have craftily brought us under: Our adversaries being the more encouraged thereunto, in regard they doe us this injury cum privilegio, and under authority act this mischiefe, without feare, without charge, saving the disbursement of one foure-pence for the Arrest, though they lay a thousand pound action upon u • , where from to free and rescue our selves, some of us have expended foure thousand pounds, and have been worsted ten th • usand pound, and yet never the nearer the recovery of our liberty, or unsettering our selves from these our bonds and thraldome.

In consideration whereof, and for the saving us from a finall and totall overthrow, and preserving our posterity from such vassallage and future destruction, as is now fallen upon us, and threatning them, it is humbly offered to the grave wisdome and consideration of the High Court of Parliament, and for the reliefe and remedy in the premises, if so it seeme fit and agreeable with the Justice of that most Honourable Court, that it may by authority of Parliament bee provided for the future.
I. That all such as are now imprisoned under any such arrest or action may forthwith bee enlarged, and full reparations made unto them for their losses and sufferings.

II. That whosoever shall hereafter arrest and imprison, or procure to be arrested and imprisoned any Merchant or other Free-borne subject, upon any action for debt, where the same is not really due and payable, shall for the first offence in such case, pay to the party grieved and imprisoned double the summe wherewith he was unjustly and wrongfully charged, over and above the debt truly due if any, the same to be levied of the lands, goods and chattels of the party so offending.

III. That whosoever shall hereafter arrest and imprison, or cause to be arrested and imprisoned any Merchant or free Denison for any summe whatsoever above a hundred pound, where there is no bond or specialty. shall first make Affidavit before some Judge of Record, that such summe or summes of money bee truly due and unsatisfied, before the party arrested, or to bee arrested, bee committed to any prison whatsoever for the same.

IV. That whosoever shall offend in the like case, for the second offence being lawfully convicted thereof, shall not only pay double the summe of the Action, but sh • ll be likewise set upon the Pillory and stigmatized, yea, and be disabled ever there-after to sue or implead in any Court of Record: And for the third offence, the same to be capitall, being a crime of such an high n • ture, and so punished as in other Common-wealths and well governed States.

V. That if the party so offending have not goods and lands, whereby to answer such summe or summes of money, wherein he shall be condemned: For the first offence, to be set upon the Pillory, and three months Imprisonment, for the second offence to be set on the Pillory, and stigmatized, and a yeares imprisonment, and ever there after to be disabled to sue or implead in any Court of Record.

VI. It is referred to your grave consideration, whether it be agreeable to the Common Law, and Magna Charta, which as to the peoples liberties by the Petition of Right, and the Statute of the 17. Carol. made for the
abolishing the Star-chamber, and regulating the Councell Board, is confirmed; and to the defence and preservation whereof, you by oath h ••• bound your selves, and so whether the same be convenient or legall to i •
prison mens bodies for debt and other faults not criminall, seeing yet the Sheriffe may not sease and take the beasts of the Plough upon any exec •
tion for debt, in favour and regard of tillage and husbandry; and so consequently, much lesse in all reason and equity the body of the man who is the master, owner and guider of the beast, without whose skill and ind •
stry the beast of the Plough is not only chargeable, but altogether unprofitable.

Lastly, wee humbly conceive that the People ought not to be vexed with close and strict imprisonment from yeare to yeare in contempt of the writs and orders of the highest Courts of the Kingdome, especially wh ••
Re vera, some of them are no • justly indebted for the value of a penny: B •• for want of accesse to a full hearing of their causes, by meanes of the C •…
terpillers aforesaid, have been turmoiled with eleven or twelve yeares sui ••… and imprisonments, even by those who are really indebted unto them, by which oppression some of us have been damnified divers thousands of pounds, and others quite ruined and undone.
